review.title: A Monte-Carlo Algorithm for Dempster-Shafer Belief
review.abstract: A very computationally-efficient Monte-Carlo algorithm for the calculation of Dempster-Shafer belief is described. If Bel is the combination using Dempster's Rule of belief functions Bel, ..., Bel,7, then, for subset b of the frame C), Bel(b) can be calculated in time linear in 1(31 and m (given that the weight of conflict is bounded). The algorithm can also be used to improve the complexity of the Shenoy-Shafer algorithms on Markov trees, and be generalised to calculate Dempster-Shafer Belief over other logics.

sections.text: 1 INTRODUCTIONOne of the most important perceived problems with the application of the Dempster-Shafer theory [Shafer, 76] was its apparent computational complexity, e.g. [Kyburg, 87], [Bonissone, 87]. This is because the Dempster-Shafer theory, as it is normally implemented, involves a repeated application of the Dempster rule of combination, which requires recording at any stage of any subset of 8 with a non-zero mass. For example, the combination of m simple support functions may have as many as 2q non-zero masses, where q is the minimum of m and 181, making the approach of shafer so computationally unfeasible. There were a number of schemes to deal with this; [Barnett, 81] showed how the calculation of Dempster shafer belief in a very specific case where all ev-sets are singlets or complements of singlets.
